STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 7, 2025
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas - Bay
1024 Professional Dr,
Flint, MI, 48532-3635
Re: License #: CB250296641
SI #: 2025SIC0000265
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• Be signed and dated.
A six-month provisional license is recommended. You must contest or agree to the
issuance of a provisional license in writing, on the CWL-4617 within 15 days, with
submission of the corrective action plan. If you do not submit the CWL-4617, it will be
treated as contested. Even if you contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must
still submit an acceptable corrective action plan
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please Samatha Way, Area Manager, at 517-243-7743.
Sincerely,
Douglas W Turrill, Licensing Consultant
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City MI. 49684
231-383-5531
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0000265
Special Investigation Intake Date: January 6, 2025
License #: CB250296641
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas Bay
Licensee Designee: Rachel Sykes
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Stevens
Agency Name: Samaritas - Bay
Agency Address: 1024 Professional Dr
Flint, MI 48532-3635
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 09/17/2025
II. METHODOLOGY

2

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12214. Compliance with the child protection
Section law.
Description (1) An agency shall comply with the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It is alleged that Bio-Mother reported child abuse/neglect concerns
during parenting time and the agency failed to report it.
Investigation A special investigation was initiated on 01/06/25 regarding the
allegation described above. All of the following interviews were
conducted jointly with a DHHS Worker with the exception of the
Complainant who was interviewed via telephone by this Department
of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Consultant.
DHHS Worker was telephoned on 01/07/2025 to discuss the
case. DHHS Worker stated she would arrange an interview with the
Bio-Mother via zoom.
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 01/07/25.
Complainant stated she filed a DHS-3200 on 01/02/25 as two
children, ages 9 and 4, presented to the hospital. Complainant
reported the 9 year old child reported witnessing violence in her
placement. Complainant reported she did not know any specifics
about the reported violence and could not offer any further
information. The Complainant did report that subsequent to filing the
DHS-3200 she learned of the incident on 01/01/25 where the children
may have been a witness to violence that had occurred at a foster
home.
Chief Administrator was contacted via telephone on 01/16/25.
Chief Administrator reported she was aware of the complaint. Chief
Administrator reported that any interviews with agency staff will need
to be prearranged through her and the agency attorney (Attorney 2),
and will need to be present at interviews.
Bio-Mother was contacted via Zoom on 01/16/2025. After
introductions from DHHS Worker and this consultant, Bio-Mother
stated she would not speak without her attorney present. The attempt
for the interview promptly ended. An email dated 02/04/2025 from
Attorney 1, (Bio-Mother’s attorney), stated his client has declined to
be interviewed.
Detective was interviewed via telephone on 02/07/25. Detective
reported he was attempting to set up interviews for 02/12/2025 with
3

the agency Foster Care Supervisor and Staff 1. Detective stated he
will let this consultant know the place and time of the interviews. On
02/07/25 an email was received from Detective stating that DCWL
would not be allowed to sit in on the law enforcement interviews as
requested. However, Detective stated DCWL could interview the
agency staff on February 02/12/2025, once law enforcement
completed their interviews.
On February 10, 2025, a telephone call was received from
Detective. Detective stated the February 12, 2025, interviews were
cancelled. Detective stated Foster Care Supervisor and Staff 1 had
retained their own attorneys and interviews would not occur without
their respective attorney’s present. Detective stated he would keep
this consultant informed when the interviews would be rescheduled.
The agency Program Manager was interviewed face to face at
the agency on 02/14/25. Program Manager reported he was
responsible for the direct supervision of the agency foster care
supervisors. Program Manager reported he did not have direct
knowledge of the Bio-Mother’s case until the 01/01/2025 incident.
Program Manager stated further that he had no knowledge prior to
01/01/2025 of the concerns the Bio-Mother had raised during
parenting times about the safety of her daughter in the foster home.
Bio-Mother’s daughter is hereafter referred to as Program Manager
reported that sometime in October 2024, Foster Care Supervisor and
Staff 1 had approached him as Staff 1 reported not being comfortable
with supervising Bio-Mother’s parenting times alone. Program
Manager reported Staff 1 had said Bio-Mother can become abusive
towards her during parenting times. Program Manager reported that
an additional staff person was to be present to support Staff 1 during
parenting times going forward.
Program Manager was asked how communication occurs between
case aids who supervise a parenting time and the assigned case
worker. Program Manager stated that expectations are that case
aides use the agency “Parenting Time Visit Log” and the completed
form is given to the case manager, in this case Staff 1.
Program Manager was asked if all staff are trained on mandated
reporting requirements and he stated that agency staff are trained in
reporting suspected abuse/neglect.
Staff 1 was unavailable for an interview throughout this
investigation. On 02/18/25 Attorney 3, the attorney for Staff 1, was
contacted via telephone. Attorney 3 stated that her client, Staff 1, will
not be available for interviews but perhaps could be in the future
when the police investigation in this case is resolved.
4

Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the agency on 02/14/25.
Staff 2 is an agency foster care worker. Staff 2 reported he had
supervised one parenting time visit between Bio-Mother and her
daughter, Foster Child A, sometime in November 2024. The
parenting time narrative for November 14, 2024, was read aloud. The
narrative states in part that Foster Child A was jumping on Staff 2
during the parenting time. Staff 2 was sitting on Foster Child A’s
bedroom floor so the Bio-Mother could view the computer screen and
Foster Child A. Staff 2 reported that he told Foster Child A that
jumping on him was inappropriate behavior. Staff 2 identified that
was the parenting time he supervised. Staff 2 reported he supervised
the parenting time visit in Foster Child A’s bedroom and Bio-Mother
was attending via Zoom. Staff 2 reported he was sitting on the
bedroom floor with his computer and from that vantage point Bio-
Mother could see Foster Child A and Staff 2. Staff 2 reported at one
point, Foster Child A began jumping on him and Bio-Mother became
upset about this stating that Foster Child A had never jumped on
grown men and was yelling who was teaching her daughter to do
that. Staff 2 reported he was correcting Foster Child A’s behavior,
informing her that jumping on him was inappropriate. Staff 2 reported
Foster Child A’s jumping on him was horseplay and he did get it
corrected, though Bio-Mother continued to be upset. Staff 2 reported
the parenting time visit was chaotic as Bio-Mother was yelling
frequently. Staff 2 reported he did not have any safety concerns
about the visit or the foster home. Staff 2 reported that he sent a
narrative of the visit via email to Staff 1 and Foster Care Supervisor.
An email dated November 19, 2024, from Staff 2 to Staff 1 and
Foster Care Supervisor summarizes and reflects what he had
reported in this interview.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the agency on 02/14/25.
Staff 3 is an agency foster care worker. Staff 3 reported she attended
a 12/26/24 parenting time visit with Staff 1 who requested support as
Bio-Mother can be verbally abusive towards Staff 1. Staff 3 reported
Bio-Mother was swearing at Staff 1 as she was angry that an
additional worker was supervising the visit. Staff 3 was asked about
the parenting time social work contact which stated that Bio-Mother
asked Foster Child A if anyone was hurting her, and she replied she
was bit by the foster family dog. Staff 3 reported she did not recall
Foster Child A reporting she had been bit by a dog. Staff 3 reported
Staff 1 asked Bio-Mother to pull over to safely continue the call as
she was driving. Staff 3 reported Bio-Mother became verbally
abusive towards Staff 1 and Foster Child A would back away from
the screen when her mother was yelling, and Foster Child A ended
the call by shutting down the lap top lid.
5

Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the agency on 02/14/25.
Staff 4 is an agency foster care worker. Staff 4 reported on
12/26/2024 she was a bystander in the office where Staff 3 was
sitting in on a parenting time visit supervised by Staff 1. Staff 4
reported she was listening in and glanced at the computer screen a
few times as the parenting time was conducted via video. Staff 4
reported the parenting time visit lasted about ten minutes. Staff 4
reported Bio-Mother had become angry because Staff 1 had Staff 3
present for the parenting time visit. Staff 4 reported on a couple of
occasions the video was muted due to the inappropriate language of
Bio-Mother. Staff 4 reported she does not recall any mention of a dog
biting Foster Child A.
Detective telephoned on 02/18/2025. Detective reported that Staff
1’s attorney, (Attorney 3), will not permit any interviews with her
client. Detective stated he would let this consultant know if the
attorney, (Attorney 5) for Foster Care Supervisor would permit
interviews.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the agency on 02/21/2025.
Staff 5 is a case aide for the agency and at times will supervise
parenting times. Staff 5 was asked if she has had mandated
reporting training, and she confirmed that she has. Staff 5
acknowledged she has supervised some of the parenting time visits
for Bio-Mother and Foster Child A. Staff 5 acknowledged she
supervised the 08/20/2024 parenting time visit during which time Bio-
Mother expressed concern that Foster Child A was being abused by
the Foster Mother. Staff 5 was presented a “Parenting Time Visit
Log” dated 08/20/204 and she confirmed she had completed the
form. Staff 5 was asked why Bio-Mother’s concern about Foster
Mother was not documented on the log and she reported Bio-
Mother’s allegations were not specific about how Foster Child A was
being abused. Staff 5 reported she never heard Foster Child A say
yes to questions her Bio-Mother would ask regarding if she was
being hurt in the foster home. Staff 5 reported that during the visit,
Bio-Mother was looking at Foster Child A’s body and there were no
concerns noted. Staff 5 reported that she did “double down” and took
Bio-Mother’s concern to Staff 1 and Foster Care Supervisor. Staff 5
reported Foster Care Supervisor stated she would look into it. Staff 5
was asked if there was any further follow up to the concern noted
and she responded she did not know.
Staff 5 was asked about other parenting times that she supervised
but did not fill out a Parenting Time Visit Log. Staff 5 reported those
parenting time contact narratives are on her computer. Chief Quality
Officer was asked to obtain those parenting time contacts and submit
them to this consultant.
6

Chief Quality Officer was interviewed face to face at the agency
on 02/21/2025. Chief Quality Officer reported she became aware of
concerns noted in parenting times shortly after the 01/01/2025
incident. Chief Quality Officer reported the attorney representing the
agency, Attorney 2, directed her on 01/06/2025 to complete an
internal investigation. An “Incident Review Report” had been
presented for this consultant’s review. Chief Quality Officer
acknowledged there is no documentation regarding follow up to the
Bio-Mother’s concerns that were expressed during parenting time
visits and this is noted in her report.
On 02/21/2025 the Chief Administrator was interviewed face to
face at the agency. Chief Administrator reported she was unaware
of the concerns noted in the parenting time visits prior to 01/01/2025.
A 05/28/2024 parenting time contact was read aloud in which the
Bio-Mother asks Foster Child A, if the foster family is hitting her
and she responds “yes”. A 06/04/2024 parenting time visit was
read in which Bio-Mother asks Foster Child A, if she is being hurt
in the foster home and her daughter responds she was hit in the
face. Chief Administrator was asked that given the allegations in
the aforementioned parenting times should a complaint have been
made to Centralized Intake. Chief Administrator responded that as
the contacts read a complaint should have been called in. Chief
Administrator reported she reached out to Foster Care Supervisor
after the January 1, 2025, incident but before the current
interview. The Chief Administrator reported that the Foster Care
Supervisor reported the Bio-Mother had repeatedly asked Foster
Child A if she was getting hit Chief Administrator reported Foster
Care Supervisor felt that Foster Child A was being lead or
coached by Bio-Mother to say yes. Chief administrator further
reported that Staff 1, the caseworker for Bio-Mother and foster
family, did not have reasonable suspicion to believe that abuse
was occurring. Chief Administrator reported there was no follow
up conducted by the agency regarding the concerns raised by Bio-
Mother.
The agency Licensing Supervisor was interviewed face to
face on 02/28/2025. Licensing Supervisor was asked who initiates
special evaluations and she responded that she would initiate an
evaluation if suspected abuse/neglect or rule violations were
involved and that her supervisor, Licensing Program Manager,
would be informed. Licensing Supervisor reported there is a
communication flow back and forth from foster care and licensing
and vice versa. Licensing Supervisor confirmed she was aware of
Bio-Mother’s case and the related foster home. Licensing
Supervisor denied that she had any knowledge of the concerns
raised by Bio-Mother during parenting time visits until Bio-Mother’s
7

arraignment. Licensing Supervisor reported no one involved in the
foster care case had made her aware of the concerns the Bio-
Mother raised during parenting time visits. Licensing Supervisor
reported she just found out about those concerns today,
02/28/2025. The 05/28/2024 and 06/04/2024 parenting time visits
were read for Licensing Supervisor. Licensing Supervisor reported
the 05/28/2024 parenting time contact where Foster Child A
responded to her mother that “yes,” she had been hit, would have
resulted in consultation with her supervisor and resulted in a
special evaluation being initiated. Licensing Supervisor reported
the 06/04/2024 allegation was clear cut and she would have
opened a special evaluation. Licensing Supervisor reported the
worker supervising the visit telling Bio-Mother to contact Child
Protective Services (CPS) if she had concerns was inappropriate
and as a mandated reporter she would have called it in to
Centralized Intake.
Staff 6, the agency Licensing Worker, was interviewed face to
face on 02/28/2025. Staff 6 is the licensing worker for Foster
Home 1. Staff 6 reported she was not aware of concerns raised by
Bio-Mother until today, 02/28/2025, as Attorney 2 had informed her of
the concerns prior to this interview. The 05/28/2024 parenting time
contact was read and Staff 6 responded that is of concern and she is
a mandated reporter. The 06/04/2024 parenting time contact was
read and Staff 6 confirmed that a special evaluation would be
warranted.
The Licensing Program Manager was interviewed face to face at
the agency on 03/04/2025. Licensing Program Manager reported
she was not aware of concerns voiced by Bio-Mother during
parenting times. The 05/28/2024 and 06/04/2024 parenting time
contacts were read aloud. Licensing Program Manager reported that
certainly opening a special evaluation based on what was recorded
in the contacts would be warranted. Licensing Program Manager
reported there was not enough information in the contacts to report
the concerns to Centralized Intake (CPS), however if there was other
corroborating information then she would call a complaint into CPS.
Licensing Program Manager reported she knew of the allegations
about Foster Home 1 by 01/16/2025.
Director of Licensing and Recruitment, hereafter referred to as
Director, was interviewed face to face on 03/04/2025. Director had
no knowledge of the case prior to 01/01/2025. The 05/28/2024 and
06/04/2024 parenting time contacts were read. Director reported that
at face value a special evaluation should have been initiated
regarding the allegation of abuse of Foster Child A in Foster Home 1.
Director also reported the supervising worker of the visits should
have documented more information instead of telling Bio-Mother to
8

call CPS if she had concerns. Director was asked if a complaint
should have been called in to Centralized Intake based upon
concerns documented in the two contacts and she replied, “I would
call it in”.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the
agency on 03/13/2025. Foster Care Supervisor’s attorney,
(Attorney 5) was also present. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if
she supervises Staff 1 and she affirmed that she does. Foster Care
Supervisor was asked if she knew of Bio-Mother’s case and she
affirmed that she does. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she has
supervised Staff 1 throughout Bio-Mother’s case and the placement
of Foster Child A in Foster Home 1 Foster Home 1 Foster Care
Supervisor affirmed that she has. Foster Care Supervisor was asked
if she knew of any concerns with Bio-Mother’s case and she reported
that she knew of no concerns other than Staff 1 reporting that Bio-
Mother had been threatening towards Staff 1 during parenting times.
Parenting time social work contacts of concern were reviewed with
Foster Care Supervisor. They are as follows:
A parenting time contact dated 04/30/2024 and supervised by
Staff 1 was read. The contact documents that a scratch was
observed on the face of Foster Child A and Foster Child A told Bio-
Mother that the previous foster care parent had scratched her. The
worker Staff 1 told Bio-Mother she would contact the previous foster
parent to inquire about the scratch. Foster Care Supervisor was
asked if she knew of this concern, and she reported that she was not
aware of the report of a scratch on Foster Child A’s face and she did
not know if follow up had occurred.
A parenting time contact dated 05/28/2024 and supervised by
Staff 1 was read. The contact documents in part that Bio-Mother
asked Foster Child A if the foster family is hitting her, and she
responds “yes”. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she knew of
this concern, and she reported that she was not aware of this, or any
follow up. Foster Care Supervisor was asked based on what the
contact documented would she have expected that supervising case
worker to inform her of this and she replied “yes”. Foster Care
Supervisor further reported that if abuse was occurring or suspected
it would have been protocol for CPS to be called and Staff 1 to inform
her of the suspected or alleged abuse.
A parenting time contact dated 06/04/2024 and supervised by
Staff 1 was read. The contact documents in part Bio-Mother asking
Foster Child A if she was being hurt in the home and she responded
she was hit in the face. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she
knew of this concern, and she responded that she did not know.
9

Foster Care Supervisor was asked what action would be taken if she
had knowledge of this concern and she reported they would assess
the situation and go from there. Foster Care Supervisor reported
various factors would be taken into consideration, such as talking to
school teachers, therapists, doctors and looking at the child’s face. If
there was reasonable cause they would report it. Foster Care
Supervisor was asked if what was documented in the contact was
enough in and of itself to warrant reporting to Centralized Intake and
she responded there are many other factors, such as Bio-Mother
prompting Foster Child A to respond yes, yes, yes, or no, no, no, so
other factors other than what is documented in the contact would be
considered. Foster Care Supervisor reported there was no follow up
to this contact as she did not know about it.
A parenting time contact dated 06/18/2024 and supervised by
Staff 1 was read. The contact documents in part that Bio-Mother
asked Foster Child A if anyone is hurting her, and she responded
yes. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she knew of this concern,
and she replied she did not. Foster Care Supervisor reported if this
had been known “we” would ask more questions. Foster Care
Supervisor reported they have discussed in team meetings Bio-
Mother’s efforts in prompting Foster Child A.
A parenting time contact dated 07/23/2024 and supervised by
Staff 1 was read. The contact documents in part Foster Child A
pointing to her privates and saying “ow”. Foster Care Supervisor was
asked if she knew of this concern, and she responded that she did
not know.
A parenting time contact dated 08/15/2024 and supervised by
Staff 1 was read. The contact documents in part Foster Child A
saying to Bio-Mother, “I want to see your body”. Foster Care
Supervisor reported that she remembers this visit and there was a
follow up with the CMH therapist as they were wondering why Foster
Child A would have said that. Foster Care Supervisor reported she
was not sure the CMH therapist was contacted.
A parenting time contact dated 08/20/2024 and supervised by
Staff 5 was read. The contact documents in part Bio-Mother
expressing concern that Foster Child A might be abused by Foster
Mother. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she knew of this
concern, and she responded that she did not know.
A parenting time contact dated 11/05/2024 supervised by Staff 1
was read. The contact documents in part that Foster Child A stated
the foster dad was being “naughty” and there was no further context.
Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she knew of this concern, and
she replied she did not.
10

A parenting time contact dated 11/14/2024 and supervised by
Staff 2 was read. The contact documents in part that Foster Child
A was jumping on Staff 2 and Bio-Mother exclaimed that Foster
Child A never jumped on grown men and somebody is teaching
her that. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she knew of this
concern, and she replied that she did remember Bio-Mother was
concerned about the height of the bed Foster Child A was
sleeping on and the agency worker was redirecting Foster Child A
to not jump on the bunk bed. Foster Care Supervisor reported
there was no follow up by the agency regarding concerns noted.
A parenting time contact dated 12/26/2024 was reviewed. The
contact documents in part that Bio-Mother was asking Foster Child A
if anyone was hurting her and Foster Child A responded that the
families dog “Snickers” hurt her. Foster Care Supervisor was asked if
she knew of this concern and replied she did not.
Foster Care Supervisor was asked if she completed monthly
supervision with Staff 1. Foster Care Supervisor reported she would
conduct monthly supervision with Staff 1 however, Staff 1 never
brought to her attention the concerns of Foster Child A being harmed
in Foster Home 1 as documented in the parenting time contacts.
Foster Care Supervisor reported she is also the supervisor of Staff 5,
the case aide who supervised some parenting time contacts. Foster
Care Supervisor reported Staff 5 never came to her about reported
harm to Foster Child A.
Foster Care Supervisor was asked about the parenting times of
concern being documented in the Updated Service Plans (USP)and
she confirmed that those contacts are documented in the USP’s.
Foster Care Supervisor confirmed that she signed Staff 1’s USPs
which contained the parenting time contacts as read to her.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Foster Care File: Initial Service Plans (ISP) and Updated Service
Plans were reviewed. An ISP dated 04/16/24 was completed and
approved by the Foster Care Supervisor on 04/24/24. A USP dated
07/15/24 was completed and approved by the Foster Care
Supervisor on 07/25/24. A USP dated 10/13/24 was completed and
approved by the Foster Care Supervisor on 10/25/24. A USP dated
01/03/25 was completed and approved by the Foster Care
Supervisor on 01/31/25. The parenting time contacts of concern as
discussed above are documented in the service plans.
11

Parenting time contacts from 04/30/24 to 12/26/24 were reviewed in
the case file.
The review of the rest of the file did not add information relevant to
the investigation.
Samaritas Bay agency file: A review of the agency file documented
that DCWL had conducted six special investigations from April 2023
to the current investigation initiated on 01/06/25. Two of the six
investigations concluded rule violations. The violations were not
relevant to the current investigation.
Foster Home file. The review of the file documented a special
evaluation was initiated on 01/25/25 and was being investigated by a
DHHS Woker. No other special evaluations were documented in the
file.
Incident Review Report: The agency conducted an internal review
of the 01/01/25 incident. The report was reviewed. The report
documents that Staff 1 and Foster Care Supervisor were interviewed
by Chief Quality Officer and Attorney 2. The report notes that Staff 1
and Foster Care Supervisor did not have reasonable suspicion that
abuse or neglect of Foster Child A was occurring in Foster Home A.
The report notes that better documentation of their reasons for not
filing a complaint with MDHHS was needed. The report also
documents the foster care file was reviewed.
Parenting Time Visit Log: Parenting time logs dated 07/11/24,
07/16/24 and 08/2024 were reviewed. The 08/20/24 log did not
document the Bio-Mother’s concern that Foster Child A might be
abused by Foster Mother.
Staff 5 parenting time documentation: Parenting time contact
documentation was obtained from Staff 5’s computer for 07/16/24,
07/30/24, and 08/20/24 and they were reviewed. The contact
narratives did not add any further information than what has already
been documented in this report.
Email: An email from Staff 5 to Staff 1 dated 10/17/24 was reviewed
and documents a parenting time visit on 10/17/24. The contact
narrative did not add any further information than what has already
been documented in this report.
Sentinel Event and Incident Reporting Policy #7.10. The policy
was reviewed and provides definitions and describes procedures for
reporting unusual occurrences internally and externally.
12

The policy states the following in part: “(3) Notification and
Documentation. All staff are responsible for immediate reporting of
incidents to supervisors who are to assess the severity and assure
reporting to the appropriate authorities if necessary. The identified
authority is responsible for notification of other parties. Including the
Privacy Officer or Corporate Compliance Office as necessary and
assuring appropriate follow-up activity and documentation.”
Staff Training Logs: Staff training logs were reviewed and
document that staff have been trained in mandated reporting.
A random selection of additional parenting time visits for 5
random foster care cases were reviewed. There were no
documented reports of abuse/neglect from the parenting time notes
reviewed.
Analysis The agency is found to be in non-compliance with this rule. Foster
Care Supervisor reported never learning of the allegations by Staff
1 and denied reading through the parenting time notes in the
service plans. Foster Care Supervisor should have been aware of
the abuse allegations in the report she reviewed and signed,
which in turn should have resulted in a report to centralized intake.
Staff 5 supervised a parenting time visit where Bio-Mother alleged
abuse and Staff 5 stated the allegations were not specific and she
did not call centralized intake to report the allegations, but did
report to Staff 1. Staff 1 supervised parenting time visits, however
there were no reports of abuse/neglect called into centralized
intake. Five of the reported parenting time contacts report
suspected abuse. There were multiple junctures in which the
agency failed to contact Centralized Intake and file a DHS-3200.
Technical Assistance
Currently the agency incident reporting policy states to report
incidents to supervisors however, if staff suspect abuse/neglect
these incidents should be reported immediately to centralized
intake and not immediately to a supervisor first.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206. Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
contact with children or parents to be a person who has the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform the
duties assigned.
13

Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Additional Thorough reviews of service plans were not conducted. Concerns
Findings were documented under parenting time visits and Foster Care
Supervisor did not review them under the Updated Service Plans.
Investigation Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the
agency on 03/13/2025. Foster Care Supervisor’s attorney, Attorney
5, was also present. Foster Care Supervisor reported she supervises
foster care workers, and her job duties include reviewing foster care
reports, attending meetings and court hearings and overseeing foster
care workers completion of job duties. Foster Care Supervisor
reported when reviewing foster care case management reports she
reviews case contacts to ensure they are being completed but does
not read contacts line for line. Foster care Supervisor was asked
about her review of parenting time contacts. Foster Care Supervisor
reported she reviews parenting time contacts to ensure they are
occurring but does not read the contacts “word for word.”
Foster Care Supervisor reported she was not aware of the
documented concerns in the service plan parenting time contacts.
Foster Care Supervisor reported that Staff 1 did not report to her
the concerns of suspected abuse occurring in Foster Home A.
Foster Care Supervisor reported she was not aware of follow up
regarding concerns raised in parenting times she was aware of,
specifically the 08/15/2024 and 11/17/2024 parenting times.
DOCUMENT REVIEW:
Foster Care File: Initial and Updated Service Plans were reviewed.
An ISP dated 04/16/24 was completed and approved by Foster Care
Supervisor on 04/24/24. A USP dated 07/15/24 was completed and
approved by the Foster Care Supervisor on 07/25/24. A USP dated
10/13/24 was completed and approved by the Foster Care
Supervisor on 10/25/24. A USP dated 01/03/25 was completed and
approved by the Foster Care Supervisor on 01/31/25. The parenting
time contacts of concern are documented in the service plans.
Analysis Foster Care Supervisor lacked the ability to perform the duties as
she did not read parenting time contacts in the service plans
which documented suspected abuse.
14

As reported by the Foster Care Supervisor, Staff 1 did not inform
her of concerns raised by the Bio-Mother during parenting times.
There was a lack of follow up by Staff 1 to the concerns raised in
the parenting time contacts.
The Foster Care Supervisor did not follow up with concerns noted
in the 08/15/2024 and 11/17/2024 parenting time contacts of
which she reported she was aware.
There was no documentation that follow up was conducted by
Staff 1 or the Foster Care Supervisor regarding the concerns
documented in the parenting time contacts.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12327. Special evaluation.
Section (1) Upon receipt of any information that relates to possible
Description noncompliance with any foster home rule, the agency must do
all the following:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon
as is indicated, based on the information received, but
not later than 7 calendar days after receipt of the
information.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The agency failed to initiate a special evaluation when allegations
of abuse were received.
Investigation The agency Licensing Supervisor was interviewed face to
face on 02/28/2025. During the interview with Licensing
Supervisor on 02/28/2025 she had reported that no one involved
in the foster care case had made her aware of concerns raised by
Bio-Mother during parenting times. Licensing Supervisor reported
the 05/28/2024 and 06/04/2024 concerns raised during the
parenting times would have resulted, if known, in a special
evaluation of Foster Home 1.
Staff 6, the agency Licensing Worker, was interviewed face to
face on 02/28/2025. During the interview Staff 6, on 02/28/2025
she reported that she was not aware of concerns raised by the
Bio-Mother during parenting times. The 05/28/2024 and
06/04/2024 parenting times were read and Staff 6 responded that
the 05/28/2024 was a concern and that she is a mandatory
15

reporter. Staff 6 reported that the 06/04/2024 concern would have
resulted in a special evaluation of Foster Home 1.
The Licensing Program Manager was interviewed face to face at
the agency on 03/04/2025. During the interview with Licensing
Program Manager on 03/04/2025 she reported that she was not
aware of the 05/28/2024 and 06/04/2024 parenting time concerns
and those concerns would have warranted a special evaluation of
Foster Home 1.
Director of Licensing and Recruitment, hereafter referred to as
Director, was interviewed face to face on 03/04/2025. During the
with Director of Licensing and Recruitment on 03/04/2025 she
reported that she was not aware of concerns in Foster Home 1
and at “face value” a special evaluation of Foster Home 1 should
have been initiated based upon information in the 05/28/2024 and
06/04/2024 parenting time contacts.
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the
agency on 03/13/2025. During the interview with the Foster Care
Supervisor on 03/13/2025 she stated that she was not aware of
the concerns documented in parenting times except for the
08/15/2024 and 11/17/2024 parenting time visits.
Staff 1 was unable to be interviewed as Attorney 3 stated she
would not be interviewed. However, per parenting time
documentation, Staff 1 was aware of the allegations as she
supervised parenting times where allegations of abuse were
reported and documented.
Staff 5 supervised the 08/20/2024 parenting time and was aware
of the allegation of suspected abuse made during this parenting
time visit.
Please note, the agency does not have a policy about
communication between foster care and licensing workers that
would dictate sharing of concerns in foster homes.
Analysis The suspected abuse reported in the parenting time contacts were
not reported to Foster Care Supervisor or to the agency licensing
department. In addition, the Foster Care Supervisor reported that
she did not read the parenting time contacts in the service plan
reports and therefore did not know of the suspected abuse.
However, Staff 1, Staff 5
16

The Licensing Supervisor, Licensing Worker, Licensing Program
Manager, and the Director of Licensing and Recruitment reported
that they were not aware of the concerns documented in the
parenting time contacts but those concerns, if known, would have
resulted in the agency conducting a special evaluation of Foster
Home A.
A special evaluation of Foster Home A was not initiated.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
It is recommended the agency create a policy that requires
sharing of information by anyone in the agency with the licensing
department related to concerns in a foster home so that special
evaluations are conducted as required.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the license be modified to a First Provisional license.
